parent.body:
Obviously we're not going to solve the centuries-old nature versus nurture debate on a quick Ruqqus thread. There are millions of pages written in support of either argument, and no clear victor has ever emerged.

Which is why I think the sanest assumption to make is that the answer is in the middle.

Yes, planning and hard work can pay off. Yes, planning and hard work can completely fall apart and leave you with nothing. That's just reality, and we have little choice but to accept it.

post.body:
There are two main ways people try to get around this fact. One group of people says that you create your own luck, your own destiny, etc., you choose to be happy or unhappy, everything is by perseverance, genes don't mean anything, etc. Basically they insist that the world is fair and the choice is yours. The other group acknowledges that we are unfairly divided by biology, external circumstances, etc. but they somehow manage to glorify it, saying that is how it *should* be. The first position is a lie. The second one is evil.

This is obviously mental gymnastics to stop us from admitting the truth. Yes, people have almost no say in their lives and nearly everything is determined for them, and no, it's not a good thing. And no, there's nothing we can do about it. It's the truth, and we're not getting anywhere by trying to get around it. You get what you are handed, and that's the end of it. It's the red/black pill.

Edit: seeing as my post was yanked to +IncelTears, no this isn't an incel problem. I mean incel problems are one thing this encompasses, but I'm not an incel nor was it the point of this post.

parent.body:
I don't think it's very quantifiable. But of course I have a lot of control. 

Today, I can work on my novel, which I'm writing specifically to appeal to a broad audience so it will sell.

Or I can apply for a bunch of traditional hourly work with an eye toward getting a steady income to supplement my wife and girlfriends' income.

Or I can work out and journal all my calories and try to improve my health and appearance.

Or I can go to a bar, get drunk, and try to make a new friendship.

Or I can go help my nearly-homeless buddy get moved into the new room he's semi-scammed his way into.

Or I can lock myself in the basement and jerk off to Brazilian women pissing on each others' faces.

I have many choices, and every choice I make will have consequences down the road. I'm not just a gallstone being pushed through the bile ducts of life.

body:
> The world is what you make of it. Give love to others and you will receive love in exchange. Work hard and apply yourself and you will succeed.

That's the first lie. 90% of your life is what you're born with. And another 9% comes from external factors you can't control. You can only choose about 1% of what you will ever experience. And yes, the other 99% gives some people more of what they want than others. Some people just have an innate ability to do everything right all the time with no thought, and others can't get the hang of anything no matter how hard they try. Some people have skills that don't match their interests. Some people look better than others. Some people are naturally more charismatic and seen as better than others. Not everyone can do everything, but only what they've been given. And it is just random what you end up with, not fair.

parent.body:
>Yes, people have almost no say in their lives and nearly everything is determined for them, and no, it's not a good thing.

The truth is in the middle, man.

I have control over lots of things in my life. Various decisions I've made have shaped my life into something that could otherwise have been completely different.

I also have no control over lots of things in my life. I can't change my genes or the circumstances of my birth.

You have to acknowledge both these facts and make the best of things that you can.

Life can be absolutely awful and it can also be pretty fucking great.

body:
> Do you believe the Bible is God's objective revelation to us?

No. The only authority we have on that is the catholic/orthodox church during the time of Constantine, which I don't trust. And an honest look at the book, or books rather, pretty much proves it's got some issues.

> Do you believe in any kind of special revelation?

There's prophecy, there's dreams, and there's typical revelations through thoughts. And there's also the moral compass.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body: In ancient times, writing under a person's name when they couldn't, or adding a gloss or interpretation to a text while copying wasn't usually considered forgery. In many cases it was actually seen as an act of nobility. However, by accident or deliberate, it could give off the wrong ideas. In any case scribes rarely omitted text but they added a lot, especially in the very early days while redaction was taking place. This is also not horribly bad in the gospels, and Jesus's teaching is still discernible in them.

body:
I tear down ideas because they are rooted not in Christ but politics. As it stands today most of Christianity is just a political and cultural movement with little spiritual focus. I can clearly see that a large number claim to believe not because they actually do, but because they value tradition (something specifically warned against), and Protestant Christianity is the tradition. You can see this because whenever Jesus contradicts the tradition, they will always choose tradition. And their biggest concerns are not the things Jesus constantly preached about, but pointless media controversies of the day. In addition, most of the focus seems to be on exalting ourselves while constantly putting others down. And we've strayed from the simple gospel into a mess of countless complicated doctrines and theology that make no difference and only serve as distractions and divisions, and often promote evil ideas. This is so much like the Pharisees that I legitimately feel like if Jesus came again now, most of us would be demanding to have him tortured and killed too.

> I would define gnostic as a system where a select person or group has exclusive access to some knowledge of God.

That defines the orthodoxy more than anything else

body:
> Oh, so the Torah Israel was required to keep as affirmed by every prophet was corrupted(but not the prophetic writings themselves conveniently)? Good luck with that theory.

Yes, and any references they have to it is from later redactions, and no the prophetic writings are also corrupt, they're completely out of order half the time. Before the time of Josiah none of the people in the bible were aware of hardly any of the laws and that is evident by their actions. For example David was a Moabite and so were his priests...something that according to the Torah is offense deserving of being *stoned to death*. The Torah also has commandments to make animal sacrifices to please God with the "savory aroma". What pagan nonsense! And then we see God *complaining* about sacrifices being made in multiple of the prophets. Read the whole of Jeremiah chapters 7-8, there are attacks on several of the laws followed by the comment about the corrupt scribes. It's difficult to reinterpret this as being about external works. Interpolation was a common practice in the ancient world, and God specifically says they don't have his law, and the reason they don't have his law is because the scribes had not been honest with it. Combined with several commands to *not* do things which are commanded in the Torah, it's hard to bend this any other way.

> And Imagine thinking Paul was the one that got it right in his trainwreck that doesn't even line up with Jesus and the gospels.

When you get rid of the fake letters and interpolations from the church fathers it lines up very closely. But I believe you're mistaken, I don't listen to Paul before Jesus.
body_html:
Oh, so the Torah Israel was required to keep as affirmed by every prophet was corrupted(but not the prophetic writings themselves conveniently)? Good luck with that theory.

Yes, and any references they have to it is from later redactions, and no the prophetic writings are also corrupt, they're completely out of order half the time. Before the time of Josiah none of the people in the bible were aware of hardly any of the laws and that is evident by their actions. For example David was a Moabite and so were his priests...something that according to the Torah is offense deserving of being stoned to death. The Torah also has commandments to make animal sacrifices to please God with the "savory aroma". What pagan nonsense! And then we see God complaining about sacrifices being made in multiple of the prophets. Read the whole of Jeremiah chapters 7-8, there are attacks on several of the laws followed by the comment about the corrupt scribes. It's difficult to reinterpret this as being about external works. Interpolation was a common practice in the ancient world, and God specifically says they don't have his law, and the reason they don't have his law is because the scribes had not been honest with it. Combined with several commands to not do things which are commanded in the Torah, it's hard to bend this any other way.

And Imagine thinking Paul was the one that got it right in his trainwreck that doesn't even line up with Jesus and the gospels.

When you get rid of the fake letters and interpolations from the church fathers it lines up very closely. But I believe you're mistaken, I don't listen to Paul before Jesus.
